constraints_details.constraints_layer_description: KEYACH Name: Tolworth Key Area of Change
AIRCZ Type:: Gatwick Airport Wind Turbine Consultation Zone:Contact: The Safeguarding Department, Gatwick Airport Limited, 7th Floor Destinations Place, London Gatwick Airport, West Sussex, RH06 0NP

description: Variation of Condition 2 (Approved Plans) of Planning Permission 18/16634/FUL (Demolition of existing bungalow and erection of 2 x semi-detached 2 bed houses with associated access onto Tolworth Park Road.) for alteration of roof design to gable ends and erection of side dormer.
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall be commenced within three years of 7 December 2018, the date of the originally approved application 18/16634/FUL, and which is subject to this application of variation.Reason: In order to comply with Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act, 1990. (As amended)

Prior to above ground works the following details shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority and thereafter permanently retained:(a) materials for all external finishes and windows (including their manufacturer's specification, colour and texture).The development shall be constructed in accordance with the approved materials.Reason: In order to ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to above ground works the following details shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.(a) refuse storage facilities in accordance with the requirements of the Residential Design SPD, 2013 (including their manufacturer's specification, colour and texture).The development shall not be occupied until the refuse storage facilities have been provided in accordance with the approved details. The facilities shall bepermanently retained:Reason: In order to ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to above ground works the following details shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.(a) boundary treatment, including walls, fences and gates (including their manufacturer's specification, colour and texture).The development shall be constructed in accordance with the approved details and the boundary treatment etc shall be permanently retained.Reason: In order to ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby permitted shall not be occupied until details of secure cycle parking facilities for the occupants of, and visitors to, the development hereby approved have been submitted to and approved in writing by the LocalPlanning Authority. These facilities shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted and shall thereafter be retained for use at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of satisfactory cycle storage facilities and in the interests of highway safety in accordance with Policy DM8 (Sustainable Transport for New Developments) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The hard surface hereby approved shall be made of porous materials and retained thereafter or provision shall be made and retained thereafter to direct run-off water from the hard surface to a permeable or porous area or surface within the curtilage of the property.Reason: To reduce the risk of flooding and pollution and increase the level of sustainability of the development and to comply with Policy CS1 (Climate Change Mitigation) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, evidence showing that the development has achieved at least a 19% improvement in CO2 emissions versus Part L of the Building Regulations and internal water usage rates of no greater than 105L per person per day have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation, in accordance with policy 5.2 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to above ground works details of the implementation, adoption, maintenance and management of a sustainable drainage system have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The system shall be implemented prior to occupation and thereafter managed and maintained in accordance with the approved details. Those details shall include a timetable for its implementation, and a management and maintenance plan for the lifetime of the development which shall include the arrangements for adoption by any public body or statutory undertaker, or any other arrangements to secure the effective operation of the sustainable drainage system throughout its lifetime.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and to prevent the increased risk of flooding in accordance with Policy CS1 (Climate Change Mitigation) of the Local Development Framework Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to commencement of any development on site, a Construction Management Plan detailing the following:A. Provision for loading/unloading materials;B. Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicle;.C. Signing system for works traffic;D. Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement ofother nuisance arising from development works;E. Means of enclosure of the site;F. Wheel washing equipment;G. The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitors; and,H. The erection and maintenance of security hoardingshall be submitted to the planning authority for written agreement. The development shall only be implemented in accordance with the details and measures approved as part of the construction management plan, which shall be maintained throughout the entire construction period.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and in order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (or any Order revoking or re-enacting this Order) no windows or other openings (other than those hereby approved) shall be formed in the walls of the dwelling houses hereby approved without the prior written consent of the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (or any Order revoking or re-enacting this Order) (or any Order revoking or re-enacting this Order) no extensions (including porches or additional dormer windows) to the dwelling houses hereby approved shall be erected within the curtilage.Reason: To safeguard the privacy and amenity of adjoining occupiers, maintain adequate amenity space and safeguard the cohesive appearance of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (or any Order revoking or re-enacting this Order) (or any Order revoking or re-enacting this Order) no outbuildings, enclosures, containers or pools to the dwelling houses hereby approved shall be erected within the curtilage.Reason: To safeguard the privacy and amenity of adjoining occupiers, maintain adequate amenity space and safeguard the cohesive appearance of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The levels of buildings, roads, parking areas and pathways within the site shall only be in accordance with details which shall have previously been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority before development iscommenced.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset and to ensure that the appearance and functioning of the development is satisfactory and to safeguard the amenities of adjoining occupiers in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012 and comply with Supplementary Planning Document 'Access for All' (July 2005).

No development shall commence until a hard and soft landscaping scheme including where applicable the retention of the existing trees shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following completion of the development and the tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority. Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced in the first available planting season, and the area shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose only.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset and in the interests of visual amenity and also that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy AdoptedApril 2012.

By the time the development hereby permitted is substantially complete, pedestrian/vehicular intervisibility splays of 2.8m x 3.3m shall have been provided in each direction where the access meets the back edge of footway, and shall be permanently retained free from any obstruction to visibility higher than 1.0m above ground level.Reason: To maintain pedestrian/vehicular intervisibility in the interest of highway safety in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to above ground works the following details shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority and thereafter permanently retained:(a) architectural details at a scale of 1:10 s of the window and door recess/reveals and rainwater goods.The development shall be constructed in accordance with the approved materials and therefore maintained as per the approved details.Reason: In order to ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises an end of terrace dwelling.The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Proposal Demolition of existing rear extension and erection of a single storey rear extension.Consultations6 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.  The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed extension would project approximately 2m beyond the rear line of the host dwelling that shows staggered rear elevation. The proposed eaves height would be approximately 2.5m and the total height would be similar to the existing one - approximately 4m. Given the proposed scale, mass and bulk and the size of the plot, it is considered that the proposal would be in-keeping with the host dwelling and the surrounding area. The proposal would not be visible within Beech Grove, as such there would be no significant impact on the existing street scene. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: It is noted that No 17 Beech Grove benefits from a rear extension, while No 13 shows the original house layout. Given the modest eaves height of the proposal and its depth, it is considered that it would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.The proposal would pass the 45 degree rule in relation to both adjoining properties and therefore it would not result in an unacceptable loss of daylight. While the maximum height of 4m could cause some overshadowing to and overbearing to the rear garden of No. 13, it would be for a depth of 2m which is, on balance, considered to be acceptable.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be  in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a semi detached dwelling. The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Proposal Erection of part two storey/part single storey side and rear wrap around extension. Internal alteration.Consultations8 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.  The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The current application is a resubmission of the refused scheme ref no 23/00511/HOU for erection of part two storey/part single storey side and rear extension, roof extension with rear dormer and Juliet balcony and installation of 3nos front and 1no rear roof lights to facilitate loft conversion due to the following reason:Given the prominent position of the host dwelling, it is considered that the proposed flat roof form over the two storey side and rear extension would detract from the character and appearance of the host property and the surrounding area. As such, it is considered that the proposed extensions would result in unacceptable harm to the character and appearance of the application property and the surrounding area, contrary to Policies D3 of the London Plan 2021, DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012 and Policy Guidance 39 of the Council's Residential Design SPD (2013).The proposed pitched roof form over the two storey side and rear extension is considered to relate well to the host dwelling and the surrounding area, as such the applicant has successfully addressed the previous reason for refusal. The scale, mass and bulk of the proposed extensions is similar to the previous scheme.The proposed part single part two storey side extension would be set back from the front elevation by approximately 5.5m. It would abut the common boundary and it would be approximately 1m wide.  Given its modest scale and the proposed design, this element of the proposal is considered to be acceptable.The proposed part single part two storey rear extension would be approximately 4m deep. The two storey element would be set along the common boundary, it is noted that it would be adjacent to the vehicular access road that serves the adjoining maisonettes. Due to the proposed scale, design and the separation distances, this element of the proposal is considered to be in-keeping with the host dwelling and the surrounding area. It is acknowledged that the proposed single storey rear extension element of the proposal would not be strictly in accordance with Policy Guidance 33 of the Council's Residential Design SPD with regards to the recommended depth (which is up to 3.5m). However, considering its modest height (approximately 2.9m)  the proposed design and its siting, it is considered that the proposed extension would appear as a proportionate and subordinate addition in relation to the host dwelling. Given the above, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: It is noted that the proposal would fail the 45 degree test in relation to the ground floor patio door at No 65 Tolworth Road, however considering that it is not the only habitable opening to the kitchen/dining area to this property, it is considered that the proposal would not result in an unacceptable loss of daylight in relation to this property. It has been demonstrated that the proposed second floor rear extension would pass the 45 degree test in relation to the habitable openings on the first floor at No 65.  With regards to the adjoining maisonettes Nos 59 and 61 Tolworth Road, the proposal would not significantly change the existing situation due to sufficient separation distance. It is noted that the existing openings on the side elevation at the adjoining maisonettes are not classified as 'habitable' openings. As such, it is considered that the proposed development due to its siting, design and scale would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

The application seeks to obtain a Certificate of Lawfulness for an existing residential C3 use (self contained unit and amenity space). The application is made under section 191 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended) and is relying on the use being in existence for 4 or more years in line with the time limits set for lawful development/uses under section 171 B of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended) Assessment The onus of proof in a LDC application is firmly on the applicant. While the LPA should always co-operate with an applicant seeking information they may hold about the planning status of land, by making records readily available, they need not go to great lengths to show that the use, operations, or failure to comply with a condition, specified in the application, is, or is not, lawful. While LPAs are statutorily required to maintain the planning register, this is not a complete record of the planning status of all land in their area. In many cases, the applicant for a certificate will be best placed to produce information about the present, and any previous, activities taking place on the land, including a copy of any planning permission he may hold. Some information, especially about the history of any unauthorised activity on the land, will be particularly within the applicant's knowledge.The application is said to relate to 456A Ewell Road and the site location plan shows the site edged in red. The planning statement states this site to be in three parts a light industrial unit marked as unit 1, a self contained residential unit marked as unit 2 and a yard with sheds marked as unit 3 said to be in residential use either separately or ancillary to unit 2. 456 A Ewell Road would appear to be as evidenced in the supporting planning statement a site consisting of a mix of uses (lawful or unlawful) and it is unclear as to whether there is one or more planning unit within the red line. It would appear that the red line of the site includes uses outside of the scope of the certificate notably the part marked unit 1 as shown on the plan within the submitted planning statement. It is considered that there is sufficient ambiguity to question whether the site has been correctly identified and whether the site location plan is correct.The application form and the planning statement state that the application relates to the elements of the site marked as unit 2 and unit 3. It is acknowledged that their is a body of evidence presented by the applicant that points towards a residential use being in existence at what is stated as being unit 2 in the supporting planning statement. However this is somewhat ad-hoc, varied in time periods and not presented in away that appears there has been a continuous use going back 4 years from the date of which the certificate application has been submitted. In regards to the residential use of the part of the site marked out as unit 3 the evidence presented is even less convincing. This amounts to a photograph or two of persons occupying the space with this giving no clear indication as to what their presence on the grounds relates to or how the area relates to unit 2.   456 A Ewell Road would appear to be as evidenced in the supporting planning statement a site consisting of a mix of uses and it is unclear as to whether these are one or more planning unit. It would appear that the red line of the site includes uses outside of the scope of the certificate notably the part marked unit 1 as shown on the plan within the submitted planning statement. Officers are not satisfied that the applicant has clearly demonstrated, on the balance of probability, that the claim is lawful, and that the use sought, residential use C3 (self contained unit and amenity space), is lawful. As such the LPA would require a fuller detailed submission to address its concerns. The fact that a LDC may be refused because the onus of proof is not discharged by the applicant does not preclude the submission of a further application if better evidence is subsequently available. A refusal to issue a LDC is therefore not necessarily conclusive that something is not lawful: it may merely mean that, so far, insufficient evidence has been presented to satisfy the LPA that the use, operation or activity is lawful. It is concluded at this stage the information submitted to date is insufficient to allow the LPA to issue a certificate.

It is considered that there is sufficient ambiguity to question whether the site has been correctly identified and whether the site location plan is correct. The applicant in any future submission should address this point and demonstrate why they consider the site identified in red to be one planning unit.

The proposed rear extension appears to connect to the existing outbuilding/garage. If the proposed extension is being joined to a previous enlargement, it will not be permitted development if the size of the total enlargement (being the proposed enlargement together with any previous enlargement) exceeds these limitations. Therefore, compliance under Schedule 2, Part 1, Class A (ja) has not been demonstrated

Officer comment: SAP and water efficiency calculations have been provided which demonstrate compliance with the requirements of Condition 7 (CO2 and water calculations) of planning permission 22/00597/FUL.The submitted details have been assessed and are hereby approved, subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details, in relation to Condition 7 (CO2 and water calculations) of planning permission 22/00597/FUL, which states:No part of the development shall be occupied until evidence showing that the development has achieved at least a 19% improvement in CO2 emissions versus Part L of the Building Regulations and internal water usage rates of no greater than 105L per person per day have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation, in accordance with policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Officer comment: A detailed landscaping plan has been submitted showing landscaping around the site. The applicant is informed that the submitted details have been assessed and are hereby approved, subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details, in relation to Condition 8 (Landscape) of planning permission 22/00597/FUL, which states:No part of the development shall be occupied until details of landscaping and planting works have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The approved scheme shall be implemented in the first planting and seeding seasons following the occupation of the flats or the completion of development, whichever is sooner; and any trees or plantswhich within a period of 5 years from the completion of the development die, are removed or become seriously damaged or diseased shall be replaced in the next planting season with others of similar size and species.The scheme shall include details of the planting and soft and hard landscaping (hard landscaping to include details of the means of enclosure) within the private amenity space for each flat hereby approved and also details of the defensible planting to the front of the flats hereby approved.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Officer comment: An enclosed timber refuse store is proposed along the boundary of the site that would house 1no. 1100 ltr. bin, 2no. 360 ltr. bins, 4no. 240 ltr. bins, 1no. 660 ltr. bin. This is sufficient amount of the refuse storage for the number and size of units, as per the Council's Recycling and Waste Technical Planning Guidance.The applicant is informed that the submitted details have been assessed and are hereby approved, subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details, in relation to Condition 9 (Bin and Recycle Facilities) of planning permission 22/00597/FUL, which states:No part of the development shall be occupied until details of bin storage and recycling facilities have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The development shall be maintained in accordance with the approved details.Reason: To ensure proper waste management in the interests of the character and appearance of the area and the living conditions of neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy SI17 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Condition 4 (Waste and Recycle Facilities) of planning permission 23/01157/FUL states: Notwithstanding the submitted plans, prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, details of waste and recycling facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The refuse and recycling facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development and shall be permanently retained thereafter. The developer and/or their successors in title shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that all refuse and recyclable materials associated with the development are either stored within these facilities or internally within the building(s) on the application site, and that no refuse or recycling material is stored or placed for collection on the public highway except on the day of collection.Reason: To ensure proper waste management in the interests of the character and appearance of the area and the living conditions of neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy SI17 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.Officer response: It is understood that there are 4 small units within the building. A refuse area is proposed, concealed behind the raised boundary wall. This would have a door that opens into the site. Within the store, 4 small 140l refuse bins are proposed, 2 large recycling bins and space for 6 no. smaller recycling boxes. The overall level of refuse storage exceeds the requirements for communal storage set out in the Council's Recycling and Waste Technical Planning Guidance and is considered acceptable.

The application seeks to obtain a Certificate of Lawfulness for an existing C3 residential unit and ancillary amenity space. The application is made under section 191 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended) and is relying on the use being in existence for 4 or more years in line with the time limits set for lawful development/uses under section 171 B of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended) Assessment The onus of proof in a LDC application is firmly on the applicant. While the LPA should always co-operate with an applicant seeking information they may hold about the planning status of land, by making records readily available, they need not go to great lengths to show that the use, operations, or failure to comply with a condition, specified in the application, is, or is not, lawful. While LPAs are statutorily required to maintain the planning register, this is not a complete record of the planning status of all land in their area. In many cases, the applicant for a certificate will be best placed to produce information about the present, and any previous, activities taking place on the land, including a copy of any planning permission he may hold. Some information, especially about the history of any unauthorised activity on the land, will be particularly within the applicant's knowledge.The application is supported by a site location plan which edges the site in red. The site, it is stated within the supporting documentation, is in mixed use. Within the red line there are uses outside the scope of uses the applicant seeks a certificate for. The supporting planning statement states that the site is divided into what the applicant calls three units. Unit 1 a light industrial unit. Unit 2 a self contained residential unit. Unit 3 amenity space with sheds ancillary to unit 2. The submission raises ambiguity as to whether there is one or more planning unit on the site and whether the red line has been correctly drawn. The certificate seeks to establish the lawful use of what the applicant calls unit 2 and unit 3 on the plan contained within their planning statement submitted in support of the application. The inference from the application is that both unit 2 and 3 have a lawful use by way of having been in use for a period of 4 or more years. It is acknowledged that there is a body of evidence that has been submitted that would suggest that there has been a residential use at unit 2. However the evidence is ad-hoc with gaps in the time period therefore not specifically demonstrating a continuous residential use for a period of 4 or more years dating back from the day of the submission of the application. In regards to unit 3 the evidence is limited essentially to a couple of photographs showing persons occupying the space on one particular day. There is no compelling evidence that allows officers to conclude that the space is linked to unit 2 or in itself has been used for a period of 4 or more years immediately prior to the submission of the certificate for a residential use.  Officers are not satisfied that the applicant has clearly demonstrated, on the balance of probability, that the claim is lawful, and that the use sought, a C3 residential unit and ancillary amenity space, is lawful. As such the LPA would require a fuller detailed submission to address its concerns. The fact that a LDC may be refused because the onus of proof is not discharged by the applicant does not preclude the submission of a further application if better evidence is subsequently available. A refusal to issue a LDC is therefore not necessarily conclusive that something is not lawful: it may merely mean that, so far, insufficient evidence has been presented to satisfy the LPA that the use, operation or activity is lawful. It is concluded at this stage the information submitted to date is insufficient to allow the LPA to issue a certificate.

The applicant should note that the red line outlining the site on the deposited site location plan includes a mix of uses and more than one unit of which part of the site edged in red falls out side the scope of the certificate. There is ambiguity as to whether the site  is one or more planning unit and whether the red line of the site has been correctly drawn. The applicant should address this in any future submission.

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

Conditions 6 (Fire Safety Strategy) -  Officers have reviewed the London Plan Fire Statement prepared by West Waddy Archadia (WWA) dated August 2023. The applicant is informed that the submitted details are agreed and that Planning Conditions 6 (Fire Safety Strategy) of planning permission 23/00205/HOU is hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.
Condition 7 (Refuse and Recycling Facilities) - Officers have reviewed the information provided and are satisfied this can now be approved.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above are agreed and that Conditions 6 (Fire Safety Strategy) and 7 (Refuse and Recycling Facilities) of planning permission 23/00205/HOU are hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.

Fire Safety Strategy - you have only submitted the guidance regarding Reasonable Exception Statements. You must complete the RES template as set out within Appendix 4 of the London Plan Guidance: Fire Safety. Please see the Householder Local List (page 32) for more information.

The fee required for your planning application is £2,730.  Payment can be made online via the Kingston council website, or via our Contact Centre on 020 8547 5002.Payment link: https://kingston-self.achieveservice.com/service/Pay_for_a_Planning_or_Building_Control_application_in_Kingston
The submitted application form has Condition 7 (Cycle Parking) and Condition 8 (Refuse and Recycling Facilites), please submit the documents for condition 7 and 8.

The submitted block plan is not labelled as existing or proposed. Please provide a Proposed Block Plan drawn at an identified standard metric scale (such as 1:200 or 1:500) showing the proposed works (hatched or shaded) in relation to the existing dwelling, site boundaries and any outbuildings on site. The Block Plan must show the direction of North and should also show adjoining properties to the side and rear and those opposite in full outline.
Please provide 'Time Stamp Photo'.
For the avoidance of doubt, please confirm the description 'Demolition of existing single storey garage, erection of part two storey/part single storey side and single storey rear extension'.

Please ensure the householder validation check list includes all the necessary documentation as required by the new local list. Please check the new local list in our website before filling the householder validation checklist.The new local list and validation checklists can be obtained via the council's website- https://www.kingston.gov.uk/downloads/download/261/validation-requirements-for-planning-applications.

The ownership certificate has not been signed in the application form, please revise the application form with the correct ownership certificate or provide the reason for not signing the ownership certificate.
We acknowledge the receipt of £145.00. There is no fee for the application for the discharge of obligation (LEG), therefore the amont £145.00 will be refunded.

25 Degree Plans - All applications that involve extensions of 2 or more storeys, or where the resultant extension/development is above 2 storeys in height, i.e roof extension must provide "25 Degree" Elevation Plans. These should be drawn at a scale of 1:50 or 1:100, they should accurately identify neighbouring building(s) and window(s) and when possible indicate the use of the room served by the window(s), and should be annotated to show the application of the '25 degree rule'. Please see the Householder Validation Local List for more information.

"25 Degree" Elevation Plans - All applications that involve extensions of 2 or more storeys, or where the resultant extension / development is above 2 storeys in height i.e. roof extension must provide "25 Degree" Elevation Plans. These should be drawn at a scale of 1:50 or 1:100, they should accurately identify neighbouring building(s) and window(s) and when possible indicate the use of the room served by the window(s), and should be annotated to show the application of the '25 degree rule'. Please see the Householder Local List for more information.

The Local List requires a completed Biodiversity Checklist for all applications. Please download and complete a copy of the Biodiversity Checklist from: https://www.kingston.gov.uk/downloads/download/261/validation-requirements-for-planning-applications

Fast Track Form - it is noted that you have paid the extra fee for the Fast Track service, but we have not received the Fast Trak Application Form. Please submit the form found here: https://www.kingston.gov.uk/planning-development/fast-track-planning-application

Householder Checklist Update - Please ensure you have provided all documents required to support your application in line with the Householder Local List and update the Checklist document with any changes you have made to your application.  Please give clear reasons if not providing mandatory documents.
